messages.message: I heard this from SE members and solution architecture teams.  It seems to fit very well with other software vendors do as well.  New functionality comes out in a .0 release and then a .1 or .2 is a series of patches over the next period of time.  It might be a model to consider as our customers have this general expectation

We do currently have patch releases. For example we are currently on 22.08.9 on the 22.08 major release branch. And patch releases include continuous bug fixes and security vulnerability to stabilize further.

The major releases are cuts that include the introduction of new features, APIs or deprecations. We don’t send new features back to old releases because they’re typically large, and risk destabilizing the older branch. You can find more details here as well (https://instabase.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ENG/pages/1739194377/Release+Support+Policy).

wanted to check in on this thread as well since we're planning on upgrading credigy to `22.08`

they'll be deploying around late october - early november and do we think `22.10` would be ready and the recommended version to upgrade to instead of `22.08`?

Is there an exact date they want the release? We’re targeting a GA date for 22.10 by the last day of Oct. In the past we have slipped a week or so in the event of bad bugs discovered during the bake period. So if they need it right at the start Nov, then I would stick to 22.08.
